article:
{{Drugclassbox
| Image = Serotonin (5-HT).svg Alt = Caption = Serotonin Use = Depression MeshID
| = D017367 Consumer_Reports = antidepressants ATC_prefix = N06AB Drugs.com =
| Biological_target = Serotonin transporter

' Selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors' or 'serotonin-specific reuptake
inhibitor' ('SSRIs') are a class of compounds typically
used as antidepressants in the treatment of depression, anxiety disorders, and
some personality disorders.

SSRIs are believed to increase the extracellular level of the neurotransmitter
serotonin by inhibiting its reuptake into the presynaptic cell, increasing the
level of serotonin in the synaptic cleft available to bind to the postsynaptic
receptor. They have varying degrees of selectivity for the other monoamine
transporters, with pure SSRIs having only weak affinity for the noradrenaline
and dopamine transporter.

SSRIs are the first class of psychotropic drugs discovered using the process
called [[Drug design#Rational drug discovery|rational drug design]], a process
that starts with a specific biological target and then creates a molecule
designed to affect it. They are the most widely
prescribed antidepressants in many countries. The
efficacy of SSRIs in mild or moderate cases of depression has been disputed.
categories: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors| Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor
